Issues.Title: fix(compiler): share identical stylesheets between components in the same file
Issues.Body:
This PR consists of 3 separate commits and updates the compiler to allow identical stylesheets to be reused between components in the same file. This is achieved by allowing strings to be handled in `ConstantPool` and actually using `ConstantPool` while generating `styles` array on component def. More information can be found in individual commit messages.

Resolves #38204.
Resolves #38203.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

Issues.Title: `RouterModule` directives cannot be tree shaken under Ivy
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> The issue is caused by package @angular/router

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: View Engine

### Description

Directives in `RouterModule` cannot be tree shaken in Ivy builds. This is because of a circular dependency which requires the use of `setComponentScope()` to be used. `setComponentScope()` is inherently side-effectful, and is the compiler's way of working around circular dependencies, where it can not import the required dependencies to define a template scope without causing a cycle in the import graph.

The solution here is to remove the cycle, and the compiler will be able to generate code that does **not** use `setComponentScope()`. This should allow compilers like Closure to tree shake unused components in `RouterModule`.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Import something from `RouterModule` (such as `RouterLink`). In the output bundle (at least for Closure, I didn't check Terser) it will include `RouterLinkActive`, despite the fact that it was not actually used in the application.

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:** `master`

**Anything else relevant?**
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èIs this a browser specific issue? If so, please specify the browser and version. -->

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èDo any of these matter: operating system, IDE, package manager, HTTP server, ...? If so, please mention it below. -->

Spin off from #38211. I was able to generate a circular dependency list by patching #38210, this is the dependency chain which needs to be broken:

```
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/components/empty_outlet.ts
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/directives/router_outlet.ts
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/config.ts
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/components/empty_outlet.ts
```

Also see http://b/162019906 for more investigative information.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`RouterModule` directives cannot be tree shaken under Ivy" (#38212)

Issues.Title: Warn or error when `setComponentScope()` is necessary
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/compiler


### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> When an `NgModule` includes components/directives/pipes with circular references, the scope for Angular components cannot be determined, as creating the relevant imports would cause a cycle that would fail Closure compilations. To work around this, the compiler defers this task to run time with `setComponentScope()`, effective setting the component template to use the entire module as a scope. This is a deoptimization which comes from a circular reference in source code. Missing this optimization means that tree shaking is less effective. For example, `RouterModule` appears to generate `setComponentScope()` and as a result, `routerLinkActive` can not be tree shaken even if it is never used.


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> The compiler should warn or error when such a case occurs (probably only if the user set a particular flag). This would allow performance sensitive code (such as `@angular/core`) to restrict itself to not include circular references to allow better tree shaking. Ideally this would print out the full path of the cycle so users could attempt to fix it.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Currently the best workaround is to grep output deobfuscated code for `setComponentScope()` and identify the modules it was used with. You then just have to "figure out" exactly how the circular dependency was introduced and what the best way of fixing it is.

I made https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38210, which is a patch to the compiler which prints out any cycled identified and then fails the build. This is a hacky means of figuring out exactly what cycle is causing `setComponentScope()`. For `RouterModule` this prints:

```
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/components/empty_outlet.ts
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/directives/router_outlet.ts
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/config.ts
/home/dparker/Source/ng/packages/router/src/components/empty_outlet.ts
```

Also see http://b/162019906 for more investigative information.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Warn or error when `setComponentScope()` is necessary" (#38211)

Issues.Title: Detect and print cycles that cause `setComponentScope()` to be used
Issues.Body:
This detects and prints any cycles which cause `setComponentScope()` to be used and deoptimize tree-shakeability.

This patch serves as a work-around for #38211.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Detect and print cycles that cause `setComponentScope()` to be used" (#38210)

Issues.Title: Share identical stylesheets between components in the same file
Issues.Body:
In rare cases, multiple components can share the same styles. For example, Material does this with `MatButton` and `MatAnchor`.

View Engine had a feature which converted `styleUrls` into `.ngstyle.js` classes with exported constants, and thus naturally deduplicated reuse of external stylesheets. Ivy does not perform this optimization by design - it was a design goal to remove all additional "shim" files.

A limited form of this optimization in Ivy is possible - within a single file, it should be possible to use the `ConstantPool` to deduplicate stylesheet text that is shared between multiple components. This would be useful both for external stylesheets as well as inline style text, as long as it's identical. This optimization is of course conditional on `ViewEncapsulation` - encapsulated and un-encapsulated styles will have different contents, and thus no reuse between them is possible.

This optimization would apply to the Material example above, since `MatButton` and `MatAnchor` are both declared in the same TS file.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue " Share identical stylesheets between components in the same file" (#38204)

Issues.Title: ConstantPool timing issue with multiple components in a file
Issues.Body:
`ConstantPool` deduplicates constants by returning a particular kind of `o.Expression` called a `FixupExpression`, to which it retains a reference. For the first usage, this `FixupExpression` transparently returns the original `o.Expression`, so nothing special happens.

Whenever the `ConstantPool` encounters a second usage of the same value, however, it creates a shared variable declaration for the value, and uses its reference to the `FixupExpression` to replace its contents with a reference to this variable instead. Thus, the original usage is updated to refer to the constant instead of the literal value.

This works as long as all potential constants pass through the `ConstantPool` _before_ any of the `o.Expression` outputs are processed. However, in ngtsc the final compilation of classes violates this condition.

This compilation happens in a TypeScript transform (in `ngtsc/transform/src/transform.ts`, within `IvyVisitor`'s `visitClassDeclaration`). Each class goes through a process of `o.Expression` generation (which includes `ConstantPool` wrapping), then reification of `o.Expression`s into `ts.Expression`s via `translateExpression`, and then updating of the `ts.ClassDeclaration` to add the new static properties. Because `o.Expression`s are immediately converted to `ts.Expression`s, any `FixupExpression`s produced by the `ConstantPool` are converted **as they are** immediately following processing of that single class. Any future deduplication based on usage of the same constants by other classes will not affect them.

In practice, this means that such shared constants are always duplicated for the first class that uses them, and all subsequent classes use the shared variable declaration. This only affects constant reuse _between_ classes - constant reuse within the same class works normally.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ConstantPool timing issue with multiple components in a file" (#38203)

Issues.Title: build(docs-infra): simplify `ExampleZipper` by removing `PackageJsonCustomizer`
Issues.Body:
Previously, `ExampleZipper` (the tool used for creating ZIP archives from our docs examples) used the `PackageJsonCustomizer` to generate `package.json` files for each example type. This had the following drawbacks:
- The generated files had to be kept up-to-date with the corresponding boilerplate files in `aio/tools/examples/shared/boilerplate/` and there was no easy way to find out when the files got out-of-sync.
- The `PackageJsonCustomizer` logic was non-trivial and difficult to reason about.
- The same information was duplicated in the boilerplate files and the customizer configuration files.

This setup was useful when we used a single `package.json` file for all docs examples. Now, however, each example type can have its own boilerplate `package.json` file, including scripts and dependencies relevant to the example type. Therefore, it is no longer necessary to generate `package.json` files for ZIP archives.

This commit eliminates the drawbacks mentioned above and simplifies the `ExampleZipper` tool by removing `PackageJsonCustomizer` and re-using the boilerplate `package.json` files for ZIP archives.

The changes in this commit also fix some ZIP archives that were previously broken (for example due to missing dependencies).

##
**UPDATE:**

In order to make it easier to see how the changes in this PR affect the final ZIP archives, I pushed two temporary commits which contained the `package.json` files from all ZIP archives:
- Before this PR (i.e. with `PackageJsonCustomizer`): ea5cf9b6b25c321eaa48848c538c4d30b51484f2
- After this PR (i.e. without `PackageJsonCustomizer`): 1afa5b9fcda656a758a4e45a85e72040aa64d134

Basically, one can see the resulting changes by looking at the latter (1afa5b9fcda656a758a4e45a85e72040aa64d134).
I looked through all changes and (unless I missed something) all changed `package.json` files contain the same changes as for example [accessibility/package.json](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38192/commits/1afa5b9fcda656a758a4e45a85e72040aa64d134#diff-c7c7cf4e524feac0de7bc88683ee8b1e) with the exception of [universal/package.json](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38192/commits/1afa5b9fcda656a758a4e45a85e72040aa64d134#diff-1d9b6695754ee6b9dedcc09e349b629f) and [upgrade-lazy-load-ajs/package.json](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38192/commits/1afa5b9fcda656a758a4e45a85e72040aa64d134#diff-8f7e2699afc4f026e6d94fb8285da227), which are slightly different.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build(docs-infra): simplify `ExampleZipper` by removing `PackageJsonCustomizer`" (#38192)

Issues.Title: Removing ViewRef causes error in Ivy
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8 ### Description I have a dropdown directive that creates a new view in a `ViewContainerRef` of dropdowns host component. If that new view also has this directive it can create another view. In `ngOnDestroy` of that directive I remove this view from `ViewContainerRef`. When parent dropdown is removed, I get an error in Ivy on destruction of nested directive created view. Seems like destruction of first view causes destruction of the second view in sync and when I attempt to remove second view I get error, because length is already updated as if parent view is removed (`length` is 1): https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/0879d2e85d29c33c10e7314e49f5e4f0cc6ce2ba/packages/core/src/render3/view_engine_compatibility.ts#L209-L211 However both views are still there in `indexOf`: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/0879d2e85d29c33c10e7314e49f5e4f0cc6ce2ba/packages/core/src/render3/view_engine_compatibility.ts#L299-L302 So nested view reports being at index of 1 and this assertion fails thinking there is only index of 0 because it thinks `length` is 1: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/0879d2e85d29c33c10e7314e49f5e4f0cc6ce2ba/packages/core/src/render3/view_engine_compatibility.ts#L321-L331 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Toggle parent, then toggle child, then toggle parent again to have them both removed https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-viewref-bug Here's working example on Angular 8 with ViewEngine: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ve-viewref ## üî• Exception or Error 
ERROR
Error: ASSERTION ERROR: index [Expected=> 1 < 1 <=Actual]
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
10.0.5
**Anything else relevant?** For some reason nested `*ngIf` gives _expression changed undefined to false_ upon appearing. It is unrelated and I've mitigated it by having nested be `undefined | true` instead of `boolean`. Never mind that.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Removing ViewRef causes error in Ivy" (#38201)

Issues.Title: PreserveSymlink doesn't work with Ivy
Issues.Body: # üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package Ivy ### Is this a regression? It works when I set `"enableIvy": false`. ### Description If I create an Angular library into a project and want to use it without deploy it (in dev mode) in an other project. * project1/projects/**library1** * project2/**src** I use `npm link ...` (or a typescript `path`) to add the library to the project. It doesn't take in consideration the angular.json option `"preserveSymlinks": true` on ngcc build (Ivy prebuild) so everything is broken because it's not the same references. If I remove the `node_modules` of project1 (alternative to preserveSymlinks), the build of `project2` says that @angular/core is missing. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Need multiple project so it's not possible to create a Stackblitz ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** Tested into Angular 9 and 10 **Anything else relevant?** Mac OSX + VS Code

Issues.Title: Angular Service worker incorrectly intercepting http redirects (302)
Issues.Body:
Hello, 

i work on with angular pwa project with spring-boot back end.

In my project, i am using Angular and Spring boot. My service worker is generating by Angular when i build my project.

I use external service (auth2) and my back-end redirecting to login page when session times out. This works perfectly fine without the service worker enabled, however with the service worker this fails.

To my observation, the mode of the Request is changed from navigate to cors. i see that in request headers

Without SW:

Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate

With SW:

Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty 
Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors

When active service worker, i have this exception :

_`Access to fetch at 'https://authentication-url.com/...' (redirected from 'https://my-w ebsite.com/file-request.json') from origin 'https://my-website.com' has been blocked by CORS policy: Response to preflight request doesn't pass access control check: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource. If an opaque response serves your needs, set the request's mode to 'no-cors' to fetch the resource with CORS disabled.`_

I tried adding ngsw-bypass=true query param to the redirect, but that did not help.

Can you help me ? I search on web but i found nothing on this problem with Angular service worker.


üõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõëüõë

Issues.Title: `--config remote` and `--config debug` are incompatible
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> The issue is caused by `yarn bazel`


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> I don't know, I've never tried this before.


### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> I had `build --config remote` in my `.bazelrc.user` which I added a long time ago for RBE. Today I needed to debug a test and was pointed at `--config debug`. When I tried to use it however, I immediately got an error that the test timeout was too long:

```
$ yarn bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
yarn run v1.22.4
$ /home/douglasparker/Source/ng/node_modules/.bin/bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
INFO: Invocation ID: ef001969-b478-4b86-994d-db49c0031214
WARNING: Streamed test output requested. All tests will be run locally, without sharding, one at a time
INFO: Build options --crosstool_top, --define, --extra_execution_platforms, and 8 more have changed, discarding analysis cache.
DEBUG: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/bazel_toolchains/rules/rbe_repo.bzl:491:10: Bazel 3.2.0 is used in rbe_ubuntu1604_angular.
WARNING: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/remote_java_tools_linux/BUILD:671:11: in hdrs attribute of cc_library rule @remote_java_tools_linux//:combiners: Artifact 'external/remote_java_tools_linux/java_tools/src/tools/singlejar/zip_headers.h' is duplicated (through '@remote_java_tools_linux//:transient_bytes' and '@remote_java_tools_linux//:zip_headers'). Since this rule was created by the macro 'cc_library', the error might have been caused by the macro implementation
INFO: Analyzed target //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc (7 packages loaded, 5022 targets configured).
INFO: Found 1 test target...
ERROR: /home/douglasparker/Source/ng/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/BUILD.bazel:24:18: Couldn't build file packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc/test.log:  failed (Exit 34): INVALID_ARGUMENT: Invalid arguments: 
  "action.timeout": Timeout 2h46m39s exceeds maximum timeout of 1h0m0s. Note: Remote connection/protocol failed with: execution failed INVALID_ARGUMENT: Invalid arguments: 
  "action.timeout": Timeout 2h46m39s exceeds maximum timeout of 1h0m0s
Target //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc up-to-date:
  dist/bin/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc.sh
  dist/bin/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc_loader.js
  dist/bin/packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc/ngtsc_require_patch.js
INFO: Elapsed time: 26.685s, Critical Path: 24.02s
INFO: 46 processes: 44 remote cache hit, 2 remote.
FAILED: Build did NOT complete successfully
//packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc                              NO STATUS

FAILED: Build did NOT complete successfully
error Command failed with exit code 34.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.
```

I updated the [`--config debug`](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/5a733629b531083fd35563ee5bc286a8954da5fc/.bazelrc#L2) definition to use `--test_timeout=3600` to avoid this error. After that however, the test just hangs. It does not execute and does not print out that it is waiting for a debugger.

```
$ yarn bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
yarn run v1.22.4
$ /home/douglasparker/Source/ng/node_modules/.bin/bazel test --config debug //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc
INFO: Invocation ID: bd00ec13-83e3-44be-9198-e94cbba45ccb
WARNING: Streamed test output requested. All tests will be run locally, without sharding, one at a time
INFO: Build option --test_timeout has changed, discarding analysis cache.
DEBUG: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/bazel_toolchains/rules/rbe_repo.bzl:491:10: Bazel 3.2.0 is used in rbe_ubuntu1604_angular.
WARNING: /home/douglasparker/.cache/bazel/_bazel_douglasparker/aef1a2fc4785727e712f458c2fbf89e6/external/remote_java_tools_linux/BUILD:671:11: in hdrs attribute of cc_library rule @remote_java_tools_linux//:combiners: Artifact 'external/remote_java_tools_linux/java_tools/src/tools/singlejar/zip_headers.h' is duplicated (through '@remote_java_tools_linux//:transient_bytes' and '@remote_java_tools_linux//:zip_headers'). Since this rule was created by the macro 'cc_library', the error might have been caused by the macro implementation
INFO: Analyzed target //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc (1 packages loaded, 5022 targets configured).
INFO: Found 1 test target...
[120 / 121] Testing //packages/compiler-cli/test/ngtsc:ngtsc; 300s remote
```

It was some time before I realized the problem was `build --config remote` in my `.bazelrc.user` file.

I understand that debugging like this requires the test to be executed locally, so `--config remote` doesn't really apply. However, it is a really easy foot-gun that leads to some pretty unintuitive behavior. Ideally there would be a way to:

1. Make `--config debug` take precedence over `--config remote`.
    * I'm not sure exactly how this could work, but I guess any flags in `--config debug` would be **probably** win over `--config remote`, since the former is a command line flag while the later is from a `.bazelrc` file?
2. Warn or error when these two flags are used together.
    * Even less sure if this is possible. No idea exactly how that would work.

Hopefully there's some way we can catch this particular error without just having tests hang forever.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`--config remote` and `--config debug` are incompatible" (#38187)

Issues.Title: Missing pipe not caught by production build with AOT
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

I have a module with a view that includes a pipe from a library. 
The library was not imported into this module and thus the pipe is not included in the module.
IntelliJ correctly flags the missing pipe but the Angular build process (even when AOT is enabled) does not find this problem

The same issue occurs when referencing a pipe that doesn't even exist at all, the builder never shows any warnings or errors

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7202374/88241836-3cbca700-cc83-11ea-81f9-6cacfa85f183.png)
The above image shows the app component including a pipe that does not exist. The pipe is highlighted red as IntelliJ recognizes the pipe has not been imported. The terminal below shows a successful production build of the project including the missing pipe. I would expect the build to fail

The example above and the repo below are both built using Nrwl NX but the same issue can be found with a regular Angular project

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Check out the following repo: https://github.com/lukebellamy053/angular-pipe-error-example
Build either of the applications, both should fail as the pipe is either not imported or just doesn't exist but the build passes in both cases

## üî• Exception or Error
There isn't one but there should be
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Missing pipe not caught by production build with AOT" (#38195)

### Release Notes

<details>

### [`v5.2.1`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/releases/v5.2.1)

#### Raw notes

[`4ee4649`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/4ee4649d) - chore: mark v5.2.1 ([#​6254](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6254))

[`b2f6918`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/b2f69183) - fix: configure debug logging in browser ([#​6210](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6210))
[`040f37e`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/040f37ec) - docs: fix link text ([#​6245](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6245))
[`9fdf2ba`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/9fdf2ba2) - chore(docs): migrate page.pdf() docs ([#​6228](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6228))
[`2331584`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/23315844) - docs(troubleshooting): install libXss in Dockerfile ([#​6236](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6236))
[`042c4a2`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/042c4a23) - chore: mark 5.2.0-post ([#​6240](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6240))

### [`v5.2.0`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/releases/v5.2.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/compare/v5.1.0...v5.2.0)

#### Feature changes

The experimental API for registering custom query handlers is slightly changed such that one registers query handlers containing two strategies: one for querying a single element and one for querying all matching elements.

The API for custom query handlers is unchanged:

```ts
__experimental_registerCustomQueryHandler(name: string, queryHandler: QueryHandler): void;
__experimental_unregisterCustomQueryHandler(name: string): void;
__experimental_customQueryHandlers(): Map<string, QueryHandler>;
__experimental_clearQueryHandlers(): void;
```

but QueryHandler is now defined as:

```ts
export interface QueryHandler {
  queryOne?: (element: Element | Document, selector: string) => Element | null;
  queryAll?: (element: Element | Document, selector: string) => Element[] | NodeListOf<Element>;
}
```

#### Bug fixes and improvements

-   The ESM build now includes file extensions in its import statements to match the ESM spec. _Note that the ESM build is still considered experimental and should not be relied on._
-   The docs on running Firefox Nightly are now much clearer.
-   We now vendor in common dependencies such as Mitt so they can be used more easily outside of the Node module resolution ecosystem.

[`313774c`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/313774c5) - feat: change QueryHandler to contain QueryOne and QueryAll methods ([#​6218](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6218))
[`82645e8`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/82645e85) - docs: better describe how to install Firefox Nightly with Puppeteer ([#​6226](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6226))
[`f1a6b8d`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/f1a6b8d6) - chore: vendor Mitt & update project structure ([#​6209](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6209))
[`fb80610`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/commit/fb806109) - docs(troubleshooting): drops obsolete dependencies ([#​5354](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5354))

### [`v5.1.0`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/releases/v5.1.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/compare/v5.0.0...v5.1.0)

#### Highlights:

The new [`Mouse#wheel`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/blob/main/docs/api.md#mousewheeloptions) API has been merged in [#​6141](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6141). It behaves similar to other mouse commands like up or down and therefore requires a `mouse.move(x, y)` for targeting the element properly.

Issues.Title: Emacs lock files cause an UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning in ng serve
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [X] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description Emacs lock files cause an UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning. The lock file `.#filename` is actually a symlink pointing nowhere and seems to break the webpack watcher. Also, the lock file is generated once I type anything into the emacs buffer (and not while saving), so there is no point in watching the lock files. ~~~~ $ npm run start [...] chunk {main} main.js, main.js.map (main) 57.7 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {polyfills} polyfills.js, polyfills.js.map (polyfills) 141 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {runtime} runtime.js, runtime.js.map (runtime) 6.15 kB [entry] [rendered] chunk {styles} styles.js, styles.js.map (styles) 12.9 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {vendor} vendor.js, vendor.js.map (vendor) 2.41 MB [initial] [rendered] Date: 2020-07-23T08:30:17.123Z - Hash: 86e8ae79c0fc07f7c92b - Time: 5696ms ** Angular Live Development Server is listening on localhost:4200, open your browser on http://localhost:4200/ ** : Compiled successfully. (node:3270950) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat '/home/vbraun/myproject/src/.#main.ts' (node:3270950) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection. This error originated either by throwing inside of an async function without a catch block, or by rejecting a promise which was not handled with .catch(). To terminate the node process on unhandled promise rejection, use the CLI flag `--unhandled-rejections=strict` (see https://nodejs.org/api/cli.html#cli_unhandled_rejections_mode). (rejection id: 2) ~~~~ Apart from flooding the console with spurious errors the watch&rebuild seems to work ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 

$ npx ng new
$ cd myproject
$ npm run start
$ emacs src/main.ts

Issues.Title: docs: update release doc to remove outdate information on patch merges
Issues.Body:
Previously instructions for merging to patch instructed caretakers
to only merge commits which were "applicable" to patch.  However,
for PRs targeting master and patch, all commits from the PR should
land in both branches.

Issues.Title: Observed the slowness while using --profile option with prod build.
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report Hi I have observed the performance issue while using --profile option. The --profile is taking more time for me while using with ngbuild --prod option. I coudl see internally we are using SMP plugin for profiling. When I run the command without --profile it executes faster. ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment
**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: Tooltip fails to hide when changing component with component reuse
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
Stackblitz link:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/tooltip-stays-material

#### Steps to reproduce:

1. Have a component that is being reused have a tooltip on a button that navigates to a different component
1. Hover over button to display tooltip
2. Click button

#### Expected Behavior
The page should change and the tooltip should be hidden.

#### Actual Behavior
The tooltip stays visible. Also, when scrolling, after clicking the button and before the new component is loaded, the tooltip is no longer being updated and will stay even when moving the mouse away or scrolling.

#### Additional Information
The same behavior was reproduced with NG-ZORRO (https://github.com/NG-ZORRO/ng-zorro-antd/issues/5604), which makes me believe the issue lies within the overlay cdk.

#### Environment
Angular: 10.0.5 and 9.1.12
CDK: 10.1.0 and 9.2.4
Browser(s): Chrome and Firefox
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Tooltip fails to hide when changing component with component reuse" (#20076)

Issues.Title: build: snapshot builds incorrectly modify semver versions
Issues.Body:
An interesting case that came up in v10.0.0 with the docs-content. The
snapshot release package and docs-content output had various
`@breaking-change` notes in the source code referring to `v10.0.0` as
certain changes are planned to be made at that point.

The snapshot deploy scripts pick up the version from the package.json
file and replace it in the output packages with a more concrete version
that includes the SHA. This meant that we accidentally also overwrote
versions as in the `@breaking-change` notes (ultimately making it
difficult for us to use the latest docs-content for the v10 release as
it was incorrect).

Example snapshot commit: https://github.com/angular/material2-docs-content/commit/e624c7130d90026574b46d12d488e470f0a18c55

We fix this by not including the SHA as part of the deployment, but
rather including the SHA when building the NPM packages. At that point,
we can safely just replace instances of the `0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER` without
having to worry about accidental version overriding.

To achieve this, we update our release stamping script to have two
modes. i.e. snapshot build mode and release mode. Framework does this
by checking the Git tag history but that seems less ideal as it makes
the release output building reliant on external factors while our
stamping is self-contained within the checked out code revision.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: snapshot builds incorrectly modify semver versions" (#20053)

Issues.Title: fix(clipboard): scroll position changing while copying on some browsers
Issues.Body:
The clipboard module works by creating a `textarea` dynamically, focusing it and copying its content. In order to prevent it from affecting the page layout, we put it at `-999em` off-screen, but the problem is that some browsers will try to move it into the view on focus by scrolling up.

These changes use `position: fixed` and anchor the textarea to the top of the page so vertically it's within the viewport.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(clipboard): scroll position changing while copying on some browsers" (#20073)

Issues.Title: feat(drag-drop): cdkConnectedTo finds all drop lists with the same ID, instead of only one
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

`CdkDropList` has `id` and `cdkConnectedTo` input properties to allow specifying an id or array of ids for which the drop lists should be connected.

The `id` input property "needs" to be unique, or better put is "assumed" to be unique - meaning when searching through drop lists to connect to by id, only the first match is returned.

Can the "need" for unique ids be removed and change the connected drop list logic to return **all** drop lists with a matching id?

From the user's perspective:

- If I want a drop list to inherently be standalone, provide a unique id.
- If I want a drop list to inherently be connected to others, provide a shared id.

#### Use Case

Connecting drop lists created dynamically, possibly defined in separate template files and with arbitrary DOM relation, **without** the overhead of having to maintain a separate list of all drop lists that should be connected, and making sure this list is properly updated and propagated to each drop list via change detection.

Instead a statically defined (or could be dynamic) id for the `id` and `cdkConnectedTo` inputs will automatically connect all the drop lists without any further coordination from the user.

Similar to what @sroettering mentioned [here](https://github.com/angular/components/pull/13754#issuecomment-436694651), but I don't think a new input property is necessary.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(drag-drop): cdkConnectedTo finds all drop lists with the same ID, instead of only one" (#20069)

Issues.Title: feat(stepper): Ability to display errors on steps that had no interaction
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

I want to be able to trigger the step error manualy (changing the state of the step).

### Use Case

In a non-linear stepper, I can go to the last step, ignoring some steps (no interaction), and could submit my data even though the form (related with the uninterected step) is invalid.

### Reproduction 
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-cxdumw

1) Click on the 3th step
2) Click on the 4th step
3) Click on Save

#### Current bahavior
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12090931/88175862-d55c1400-cbfc-11ea-9cfa-cabd67ee208d.png)

#### Expected behavior
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12090931/88176058-1fdd9080-cbfd-11ea-9762-cc89a1382877.png)

### Observation
As a workaround to get my desired behavior, you can uncomment the `save()` function content and try the reproduction steps from above again.

`this.matStepper.steps.forEach(x => x.select());`

This way the [interacted property](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/cc1e0fe5964a23eeb4a68e9d090539cb9cdcc04b/tools/public_api_guard/cdk/stepper.d.ts#L15) is set to true, and error state is displayed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(stepper): Ability to display errors on steps that had no interaction" (#20068)

Issues.Title: build: docs generation script adding extra file extension
Issues.Body:
The `indexFilename` in the `ExampleData` that we were publishing to npm includes the file extension, but because material.angular.io assumes that it's just the filename, we end up adding the extension twice when we generate a Stackblitz example (see https://github.com/angular/material.angular.io/blob/master/src/app/shared/stack-blitz/stack-blitz-writer.ts#L91). This doesn't seem to break the example, but it gets highlighted as invalid in the editor.

The error seems to be a side-effect of d00cb12582ab1265d38bb0f3012b7bd1adced97f where some things were cleaned up. I've fixed the issue by stripping away the extension like before.

Fixes #20061.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: docs generation script adding extra file extension" (#20065)

Issues.Title: fix(material/progress-spinner): progress-spinners with diameter less than or equal to 10 do not show
Issues.Body:
As @paulferaud  pointed out in #19469, using `BASE_STROKE_WIDTH` when calculating the spinner circle radius is causing issues, such as the progress spinner becoming invisible if the diameter is less than or equal to 10.

The proposed solution is to use the current stroke width instead of the `BASE_STROKE_WIDTH` constant for calculating the spinner radius.

This one change will also stop the spinner circle extending beyond its parent `mat-progress-spinner` dimensions for custom stroke widths (see screenshot and stackblitz below), which I presume is an improvement.

https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-jsceqa?file=src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.html 

Before commit:
![issue-19469-before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8414922/88111224-728b5e00-cba5-11ea-99fc-8637a2de6da0.png)

After commit:
![issue-19469-after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8414922/88111218-70290400-cba5-11ea-8261-504f83021922.png)


Fixes #19469
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/progress-spinner): progress-spinners with diameter less than or equal to 10 do not show" (#20062)

Issues.Title: coerceBooleanProperty falsy value handling
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a component using a `mat-slide-toggle` with `[checked]="0"` (or any non-boolean falsy value ([reference here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Falsy)) for which the `!= null` check shown below does not pass).

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/4a1b24c42eed23647a65776840ef5f6f83de461e/src/cdk/coercion/boolean-property.ts#L17

#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

The `mat-slide-toggle` should be unchecked.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The `mat-slide-toggle` is checked.
This leads to awkward code in templates with boolean checks in interpolations not matching the same checks in the `mat-slide-toggle [checked]` input.

#### Environment

- Angular:  `~8.1.1`
- CDK/Material: `~8.1.1`
- Browser(s): Chrome, Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Linux Mint
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "coerceBooleanProperty falsy value handling" (#20052)

Issues.Title: build: update to latest MDC canary and disable slider
Issues.Body:
Updates to the latest canary version and temporarily disables the MDC-based slider. We have to disable the slider, because MDC have introduced a completely new implementation that will take some work to reintegrate into our current slider and we don't want our CI to fail until then.

I went with this approach of disabling the slider where it's basically a no-op, because we can't simply exclude the build target without modifying a ton of shared files which will be hard to clean up once we start to actually implement it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: update to latest MDC canary and disable slider" (#20054)
